title: 112_hr1475
content: The Act may be cited as the "Domestic Refugee Resettlement Reform and Modernization Act of 2011". The Congress finds that the United States has increased efforts to resettle Iraqi refugees since 2007, with many refugees in Syria and Jordan lacking legal status and access to healthcare. These refugees, often victims of torture or persecution, may have supported American military operations and are in need of protection and support upon arrival in the US. In fiscal years 2008 and 2009, thousands of Iraqi refugees were resettled in the United States. In fiscal year 2009, refugees resettled in the United States receive 36 months of cash and medical assistance, but in reality, they only get 8 months of support. Despite facing challenges like the recession, refugees can become self-sufficient with proper resettlement support. However, many struggle to find employment within the 8-month benefit period. State refugee offices and voluntary agencies lack adequate resources to assist refugees effectively. State refugee offices and voluntary agencies lack resources and data to increase staffing levels for the large number of refugees needing services. ORR funding formulas are retroactive, not reflecting large increases in refugee admissions. US resettlement policy assumes quick self-sufficiency for refugees, despite specific vulnerabilities hindering integration. Some refugees may have mental health issues from trauma or torture. Refugee services are hindered by lack of resources and data, with mental health issues from trauma or torture being a significant barrier to self-sufficiency and integration. Secondary migration is not properly tracked, and support is needed for organizations providing refugee services. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. This Act defines terms like "national resettlement agency" as voluntary agencies providing services to refugees, "community based organization" as nonprofits offering various services to refugees, and "Assistant Secretary" as the official overseeing refugee resettlement. SEC. 4. EFFECTIVE DATE. The Act will take effect 90 days after enactment. SEC. 5. ASSESSMENT OF THE REFUGEE DOMESTIC RESETTLEMENT PROGRAM. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study on the effectiveness of domestic refugee resettlement programs, focusing on defining self-sufficiency, program effectiveness, unmet needs, and budgetary resources of the Office of Refugee Resettlement. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on domestic refugee resettlement programs, including budgetary resources, community organizations' role, and recommendations for program improvement. A report will be submitted to Congress within 2 years of the Act's enactment. The Office of Refugee Resettlement will be elevated according to Section 6 of the Act. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to elevate the Office of Refugee Resettlement, appointing an Assistant Secretary of Health and Human Services for Refugee and Asylee Resettlement. Conforming amendments change references from "Director" to "Assistant Secretary" throughout the Act. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to appoint an Assistant Secretary of Health and Human Services for Refugee and Asylee Resettlement, replacing references to the Director with the Assistant Secretary throughout the Act. SEC. 7. REFUGEE ASSISTANCE. Amendments to the Social Services Funding under the Immigration and Nationality Act allocate funds based on the number of refugees and other eligible populations residing in each State. The Immigration and Nationality Act now requires an annual report on secondary migration, detailing departures and arrivals, reasons for migration, and the impact on hosting states. The Immigration and Nationality Act now mandates an annual report on secondary migration, including reasons for migration and its impact on hosting states. Amendments to the Act require assistance to be provided to secondary migrant refugees meeting eligibility requirements. The Assistant Secretary must issue a proposed rule within 90 days of enactment to allocate grants and contracts based on a new formula. Grants and contracts will be allocated based on amendments made by subsection (c) and public comment will be solicited. The amendment made by this section will be effective on the first day of the first fiscal year after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 8. RESETTLEMENT DATA. The Assistant Secretary will enhance data analysis for refugee resettlement, focusing on tracking refugees with medical conditions and urgent needs. This includes collaborating with various organizations to monitor trends in mental and physical health cases among refugees. The Assistant Secretary will collect data on refugee housing needs, employment status, and self-sufficiency post-arrival. This data will be updated annually and reported to Congress.
